page.title: 15FARLEIGH HUNGERFORD
page.content: AT THE EXTREME EASTERN EDGE OF THE AREA, LIES THE INTERESTING VILLAGE OF {FARLEIGH HUNGERFORD.}IT IS CHIEFLY KNOWN FOR ITS CASTLE RUINS AND ITS RACING CIRCUIT, BOTH OF WHICH ARE SITED OUTSIDE THE BLOCK, BUT THERE ARE BELIEVED TO BE TUNNELS CONNECTING THE CASTLE TO THE CHURCH (SEE PAGE 14), HINTON PRIORY (SEE PAGE 1) AND NORTON ST. PHILIP, A NEIGHBOURING VILLAGE. THERE IS A FARM NEAR THE CHURCH WHICH USED TO BE IN THE CASTLE, BUT IT WAS MOVED OUT WHEN THE CASTLE WAS OPENED TO THE PUBLIC. THE FARM HAS 200 HEAD OF CATTLE AND GROWS OATS FOR A CEREAL COMPANY. THE SURROUNDING AREA IS VERY RURAL, WITH AN ABUNDANCE OF WILD BIRDS, PLANTS AND INSECTS. OPPOSITE THE CHURCH IS A ROW OF COTTAGES, WHICH USED TO BE THE VILLAGE SCHOOL, AND A WATER TOWER AND PUMP, WHICH SUPPLIED THE VILLAGE WITH WATER.
